intro: Quercus caraballoana, commonly known as the Caraballoan oak, is a species of flowering plant in the beech family, Fagaceae. It is native to the mountainous regions of Central America, particularly in southern Mexico and northern Guatemala. This evergreen tree can grow up to 20 meters tall and is characterized by its thick, fissured bark and elliptical, leathery leaves. The plant produces acorns that are enclosed in a cupule, which is typical of the Fagaceae family. It plays an important ecological role in its native habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
